RL.description: Regular Grammars are another way to define a regular language.
RL.question: What are Regular Languages?

RG.description: A Regular Grammar is a special type of grammar.
RG.question: What is true about grammars?
answer: They are used to define languages
Grammar $G$ can be defined as $G = (V, T, S, P)$
choices: They are used to define languages
They are used to accept Languages
Grammar $G$ can be defined as $G = (V, T, S, P)$
correctFeedback: Machines (like DFAs and NFAs) accept languages, while grammars define or describe them.

variable.description: Suppose we have the grammar $G = (V, T, S, P)$
variable.question: What is $V$?
incorrectFeedback: Did you pick everything that $V$ is?

terminal.description:
Suppose we have the grammar $G = (V, T, S, P)$ where
$V =$ variables (or non-terminals) $= A, B, \ldots Z$
terminal.question: What is T?

production.description:
Suppose we have the grammar $G = (V, T, S, P)$ where
$V =$ variables (or non-terminals) $= A, B, \ldots, Z$
$T =$ terminals $= a, b, \ldots, z, 0, 1, \ldots 9$
production.question: What is P?

start.description:
Suppose we have the grammar $G = (V, T, S, P)$ where
$V =$ variables (or non-terminals) $= A, B, \ldots, Z$
$T =$ terminals $= a, b, \ldots, z, 0, 1, \ldots 9$
$P =$ productions (replacement rules)
start.question: What is S?

sets.description:
Suppose we have the grammar $G = (V, T, S, P)$ where
$V =$ variables (or non-terminals) $= A, B, \ldots, Z$
$T =$ terminals $= a, b, \ldots, z, 0, 1, \ldots 9$
$P =$ productions (replacement rules)
$S =$ start symbol
sets.question: Select all the things in the definition that are sets.

linear.description:
Definition: A grammar is linear if has a single variable in the RHS of every production rule (and a single variable on the LHS of every production rule).
So, all productions are of one of these forms:
$A \rightarrow xB$
$A \rightarrow Cx$
$A \rightarrow x$
where $A, B, C \in V, x \in \ T^*$
linear.question: Why is the grammar shown to the left considered linear?
answer: Each production rule has at most one variable on the RHS
Each production rule has at most one variable on the LHS
choices: Each production rule has at most one variable on the RHS
Each production rule has at most one variable on the LHS
correctFeedback: This might seem odd, but some types of grammars are allowed to have more than one symbol (terminals or non-termals) on the left-hand side. Of course, these are not linear, or even regular.

right.description:
Definition: A Right-linear grammar is a special case of a linear grammar. If a grammar is linear, and the variable on the RHS, if there is one, always occurs at the right end of the rule, then the grammar is called a right-linear grammar. For example, this grammar is right-linear:
$A \rightarrow xB$
$A \rightarrow xC$
$A \rightarrow y$
where $A, B, C \in V$ and $x, y \in T^*$
right.question: Why is the grammar shown on the left right linear?
answer: Each production rule has at most one variable, and if that variable exists, it is located at the right of the RHS
choices: Each production rule has at most one variable on the RHS
Each production rule has at most one variable on the LHS
Each production rule has at most one variable, and if that variable exists, it is located at the right of the RHS
Each production rule has at most one variable, and if that variable exists, it is located at the left of the RHS

left.description:
A left-linear grammar is simmilar to a right-linear grammar. But in each production rule the occurance of any variable, if there is one, is at the begining of the RHS. For example,
$A \rightarrow Bx$
$A \rightarrow Cy$
$A \rightarrow x$
where $A, B, C \in V, x, y \in T^*$
left.question: Why is the grammar shown on the left left linear?
answer: Each production rule has at most one variable, and if that variable exists, it is located at the left of the RHS
choices: Each production rule has at most one variable on the RHS
Each production rule has at most one variable on the LHS
Each production rule has at most one variable, and if that variable exists, it is located at the right of the RHS
Each production rule has at most one variable, and if that variable exists, it is located at the left of the RHS

regular.description: Definition: A regular grammar is right-linear OR left-linear grammar
regular.question:
What is the type of the following grammar?
G = ($\{S\}, \{a,b\}$,S,P),
P =
$S \ \rightarrow abS$
$S \ \rightarrow \ \lambda$
$S \ \rightarrow Sab$
correctFeedback: This grammar is linear, because every rule is of the right form. BUT, it is not regular. Because a regular grammar cannot mix right-linear and left-linear rules.

Ex2.description: Definition: A regular grammar is right-linear OR left-linear grammar
Ex2.question:
What is the type of the following grammar?
G = ($\{S\}, \{a,b\}$,S,P),
P =
$S \ \rightarrow abS$
$S \ \rightarrow \ \lambda$
$S \ \rightarrow aS$

Ex3.description: Definition: A regular grammar is right-linear OR left-linear grammar
Ex3.question:
What is the type of the following grammar?
G = ($\{S\}, \{a,b\}$,S,P),
P =
$S \ \rightarrow Sab$
$S \ \rightarrow \ \lambda$
$S \ \rightarrow Sa$

Ex4.description: Definition: A regular grammar is right-linear OR left-linear grammar
Ex4.question:
What is the type of the following grammar?
G = ($\{S\}, \{a,b\}$,S,P),
P = $S \ \rightarrow abS\mid \lambda \mid aS$
correctFeedback: This is just a shorter way to write the three prodcution rules for $S$ on one line.
